While therefore he is not concerned with Afghan affairs, we can hardly object to his taking an interest in suspicious travellers who cross the frontier into Persia - though the real reason may be that 8.I.M.S. have time on their hands. It is rather surprising that Tehran should have suggested that the Indian security authorities in Sast Persia should control the frontier. It is a long frontier and though the roads are few enough it offers plenty of opportunity for the sort of travellers the Minister of State has in mind who are not particularly addicted to using roads when they wish to cross frontiers. MOST SECRET In view of the presence of Axis Legations in Kabul and reports of the activities of their intelligence services, S.I.M.E. are anxious that movements of travellers between Afghanistan and Persia in both directions should be effectively controlled. 2. I understand that in June 1942 His Majesty’s Legation at Tehran requested Persian authorities to consult them before granting any exit visas for Turkey and Iraq but that since then arrangements have also been made for them to be consulted by the Persian police before e£Lt visas for Afghanistan are granted. There is however, no satisfactory control of travellers arriving from Afghanistan and it is desirable that His Majesty’s Legation at Kabul should if possible keep Tehran fully and lucidly informed of all such travellers. Could this be arranged? 3. Tehran have suggested that most effective step would be for Indian Security authorities in East Persia to control the frontier. I should be grateful to learn whether this is possible. [Copies sent to Mr. Armstrong and to Telegraph Branch, India Orfice, for repetition £ ^ OTP

mods.abstract: This file consists primarily of letters and notes between the Government of Persia and the Foreign Office regarding the control and safety of travellers between Afghanistan and Persia.
